Dear Mr. GONZALEZ:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
07/27/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 If repeat violation, explanation of why the previous corrective action plan
was not successful.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has not
been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
One of three new hire employee files reviewed documentation was completed more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment. Staff was hired on August 9, 2021,
but the central registry clearance was obtained on June 10, 2021.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary period
or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a written
evaluation of the employee’s performance annually
thereafter.
1

One of two new hire employees’ files reviewed where a six-month evaluation was
required, lacked a completed evaluation.
Repeat Violation Established
2021 Renewal, CAP approved 9/14/21
R 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing; storage space.
(1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all
of the following:
(b) The method used to accurately account for and
return possessions and money to the resident or guardian
upon discharge.
One of three open youth files reviewed lacked documentation of a clothing inventory.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person
whose function is covered by these rules has participated
in a minimum of 50 clock hours of planning training within
the first year of employment and a minimum of 25 clock
hours of training annually thereafter related to the
employee's job function. At least 16 of the 50 hours
provided in the first year shall be orientation provided prior
to the assumption of duties.
One of four staff files reviewed requiring 16 hours of orientation during this period
under review lacked documentation of orientation being completed prior to the staff
member assuming the duties of their position.
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation of
an admission physical examination for each resident,
unless an earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year prior
to admission or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after admission.
One of three open youth files reviewed lacked a medical examination within 30 days
after admission.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 If a youth refuses to attend a medical appointment, that should be documented
on the medical refusal form.
 The agency has multiple case records containing youth information, it is
recommended that youth have one uniform file per the licensing rule.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Youth who have the capacity to understand should be provided with the
treatment plan and sign off.
 Be consistent with completing all required reports for each youth.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to their 2021 Renewal
Inspection Report. There were three violations, one of which is a repeat violation
during this inspection for employee performance evaluations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted that there have been no unplanned discharges of
children since the last inspection. CA noted that since the last review, there have
been no barriers or systemic factors that have impacted rule compliance. As a part of
the approved CAP based on the 2021 Renewal Inspection Report, the facility
implemented a "buddy" system wherein a designated "buddy" supervisor from
another program was required to sign off on the pre-hire checklist before an offer of
employment was made. The facility also requested HR send an automated reminder
through their online system Cornerstone to ensure performance reviews were
completed timely & CA noted this process produced results. CA reported that review
of employee files on "Annual Days" in collaboration with HR personnel has proven
3

effective in having updated driver's licenses for all employees. These processes were
intended to provide additional oversight to ensure compliance with R400.4113. CA
identified R400.12205 Required Staff as a rule that needs improvement and noted
that the goal is to become fully staffed by enhancing recruitment efforts. The facility
plans to partner with HR, beginning 8/31/22, and finance to offer cash incentives for
employees to recruit friends, strategize ways to attract qualified candidates/increase
candidate pool and partner with local colleges and universities to recruit talented
graduates.
Interviews
One youth reported that everything was going well, and he liked living there. He did
indicate there are no good trash cans in the facility and there are a lot of flies in the
home, specifically in the kitchen. Another youth noted that he did not like living in the
facility, wants more money and wants to go on outings. However, in talking with staff,
the youth is not participating in programming as required and therefore has not
earned additional privileges.
Staff interviews were very positive. All staff interviewed reported enjoying working for
Bethany Christian Services and enjoyed their roles at Casa Del Sol. One staff stated
the only concern was not knowing who is filling in each of the management roles as a
supervisor has been out on extended medical leave. The staff noted that it gets
confusing which supervisor to consult with for each purpose and it does not seem to
be clearly laid out. The staff also noted that there is not a lot of privacy for direct case
managers to complete their work and print documents. However, the staff also
reported they felt heard and supported regarding that need as the organization is
working on cleaning out the back office and installing an additional printer to
accommodate.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility continue their regular license.
